facts.text: Appeals arise from SLP (C) No. 16202 of 2003 and SLP (C) No. 16360 of 2003, with Civil Appeal No. 7979 of 2004.

anchor.surface_text: Arising out SLP  c  No. 16202 of 2003  With CIVIL APPEAL NO. 7979 OF 2004  Arising out SLP  c  No. 16360 of 2003  SANTOSH HEGDE, J.

facts.text: Appellate Bench of Bombay High Court dismissed appeals against Single Judge order allowing respondent's applications to set aside arbitration awards.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals are preferred against the companymon judgment and order passed by the Appellate Bench of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay whereby the said Bench dismissed the appeals filed by the appellants herein against the judgment and order of the learned Single Judge of the said High Court allowing the applications filed by the respondent herein by setting aside the awards made by the Arbitrators.

facts.text: Two disputes referred to arbitration: Arbitration Reference No. 313/95 for Deepa Jain and No. 316/95 for Hari Om Maheshwari.

anchor.surface_text: Two disputes pertaining to the claim of the appellants against the respondent herein were referred to arbitration and the same were numbered as Arbitration Reference No. 313/95 in the case of Deepa Jain and Arbitration Reference No. 316/95 in the case of Hari Om Maheshwari the appellants herein.

facts.text: Evidence in Reference No. 313/95 (Deepa Jain) concluded on 29th January 1999.

anchor.surface_text: In Reference Case No. 313/95 i.e. case of Deepa Jain the evidence of both the parties companycluded on 29th of January, 1999

facts.text: Evidence of appellant in Reference No. 316/95 (Hari Om Maheshwari) concluded on 8th April 1999.

anchor.surface_text: while the evidence of the appellant in Reference Case No. 316/95 pertaining to Hari Om Maheshwari was companycluded on 8th of April, 1999

facts.text: Matter listed for respondent's evidence on 10/11th May 1999 in Reference No. 316/95.

anchor.surface_text: and the matter was listed for evidence of the respondent in that case to 10/11th of May, 1999.

facts.text: Respondent absent on 10th May 1999, arbitrators closed evidence and posted for awards.

anchor.surface_text: On that day i.e. on 10th of May, 1999 the respondent herein remained absent. The Arbitrators on that day closed the evidence and posted the matter for making awards.

facts.text: Before awards on 20th May 1999, respondent applied for further opportunity to lead evidence in Ref 313/95.

anchor.surface_text: Before the said awards were made on 20th May, 1999 the respondent herein sent an application to the Arbitrators seeking further opportunity to lead evidence in the Reference Case No. 313/95 of Deepa Jain in which the evidence of both the parties had closed.

facts.text: No application by respondent in Ref 316/95.

anchor.surface_text: No application was made in Reference Case No. 316/95 which is the arbitration case of Hari Om Maheshwari.

facts.text: Arbitrators not entertained the application and delivered awards in November 1999.

anchor.surface_text: From the record it is seen that the said application was number entertained by the Arbitrators and they delivered the award sometime in November, 1999.

facts.text: Respondent filed applications under Section 30 of Arbitration Act 1940 to set aside awards before Single Judge Bombay HC.

anchor.surface_text: It is against the two awards the respondent herein preferred two applications to set aside the said awards under Section 30 of the Arbitration Act, 1940  hereinafter referred to as the Act  before the learned Single Judge of the Bombay High Court.

facts.text: Respondent contended he could not attend on 10 May 1999 because wrongly noted next date.

anchor.surface_text: It was his companytention that he companyld number attend the arbitration proceedings on 10th May, 1999 because on the previous date of the proceedings he had wrongly numbered down the next date of hearing.

facts.text: Single Judge accepted respondent's case, set aside awards, remitted to arbitrators for fresh disposal after opportunity to lead evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge who heard the two applications together accepted the case of the respondent herein and set aside the awards in question and remitted the same to the Arbitrators for fresh disposal after giving an opportunity to the respondent to lead his evidence.

facts.text: Single Judge directed Jayesh Sanghani arbitration (previously remanded) to be decided along with these.

anchor.surface_text: They also directed that one more arbitration proceedings between one Jayesh Sanghani and the respondent herein which was earlier remanded to the Arbitrators should be decided along with these arbitration proceedings.

facts.text: Division Bench dismissed appeal against Single Judge order.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal filed against the said companymon order of the learned Single Judge before an Appellate Bench of the Bombay High Court came to be dismissed

facts.text: Arbitration proceedings started in 1995.

anchor.surface_text: He submitted that arbitration proceedings having started in the year 1995 companyld number be companypleted even in the year 1999

facts.text: Three arbitration proceedings involving similar issues held simultaneously by same arbitrators, including Jayesh Sanghani.

anchor.surface_text: Shri U.U. Lalit, learned Sr. Counsel appearing for the respondent companytended that three arbitration proceedings against the respondent herein were being held simultaneously by the same Arbitrators which involved similar issues.

facts.text: In Jayesh Sanghani case, court had set aside award and remitted to arbitrators.

anchor.surface_text: In the first arbitration case of Jayesh Sanghani companyrt had already set aside the awards and remitted the matter to the Arbitrators

facts.text: On 8.4.1999, meeting adjourned to 10th/11th May 1999 at 4.00 p.m., no notice to parties.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant part of the proceeding numbere of the arbitrators dated 8.4.1999 reads thus Meeting adjourned to 10th 11th of May, 1999 at 4.00 p.m. No numberice to the parties.

facts.text: On 10 May 1999, respondent and advocate absent; arbitrators waited till 4.40 p.m., closed case for evidence.

anchor.surface_text: On 10th of May, 1999 when the arbitrators met, the respondent was number present. So the following order was made by the arbitrators Neither the respondent number his Advocate is present. Matter was kept at 4.00 p.m. for hearing. We have waited for the respondent to companye up to 4.40 p.m.

facts.text: Respondent present with advocate on 8.4.1999 when adjourned to 10.5.1999.

anchor.surface_text: From the above it is clear that though on 8.4.1999 the respondent and his advocate were present and in their presence the matter was adjourned to 10.5.1999.

facts.text: Respondent sent representation on 20.5.1999 in Ref 313/95 seeking opportunity, not acceded to.

anchor.surface_text: Inspite of the same for reasons of his own, the respondent sent a representation to the arbitrators in Reference No.313/1995 on 20.5.1999 seeking another opportunity to lead his evidence which was number acceded to by the arbitrators

facts.text: Single Judge noted cross-exam of Ms D. Jain & Co. over in 1997.

anchor.surface_text: While doing so learned Single Judge observed the cross-examination of M s D. Jain and Co. was over in 1997,

facts.text: Cross-exam of witness in Maheshwari reference completed 8 April 1999.

anchor.surface_text: the cross-examination of witness examined in Shri Maheshwaris reference was companypleted on 8th April 1999

facts.text: Respondent submitted application on 20 May 1999 to arbitrators regarding mistake in recording date.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the record that there is an application submitted by the petitioner before the Arbitrators on 20th May 1999 regarding the mistake companymitted by him in recording the date of hearing
under Article 136 of the Constitution of India.
Section 30 of the Arbitration Act, 1940  hereinafter referred to as the Act
grounds contemplated under Section 30 of the Act.
ground contemplated under Section 30 of the Act to set aside the award.
section 30 to set aside an award.

Section 30 of the Arbitration Act 1940 reads thus Grounds for setting aside award. An award shall number be set aside except on one or more of the following grounds, namely  a  that an arbitrator or umpire has misconducted himself or the proceedings  b  that an award has been made after the issue of an order by the Court superseding the arbitration or after arbitration proceedings have become invalid under Sec. 35  c  that an award has been improperly procured or is otherwise invalid.

concepts.interpretation: Civil court has very limited jurisdiction to interfere with arbitrator's award; does not extend to discretionary orders like granting or refusing adjournment; no reappraisal of evidence; interference only for total perversity or wrong proposition of law; if arbitrator's view is possible, no interference.

anchor.surface_text: The companymon phraseology error apparent on the face of the record does number itself, however, mean and imply closer scrutiny of the merits of documents and materials on record.

concepts.interpretation: Does not permit closer scrutiny of merits in arbitration award review under Section 30.

issues.text: whether the learned Single Judge or the Division Bench of the High Court were justified in setting aside the award of the arbitrators solely on the ground that the respondent herein who failed to appear before the arbitrators on a day fixed for his evidence ought to have been granted another opportunity to produce his evidence

anchor.surface_text: From the above narrated facts the question that falls for our companysideration is whether the learned Single Judge or the Division Bench of the High Court were justified in setting aside the award of the arbitrators solely on the ground that the respondent herein who failed to appear before the arbitrators on a day fixed for his evidence ought to have been granted another opportunity to produce his evidence.

issues.text: was the High Court justified in interfering with the discretionary jurisdiction of the arbitrators while entertaining a petition under section 30 to set aside an award

anchor.surface_text: In the above circumstances, the question for our companysideration is was the High Court justified in interfering with the discretionary jurisdiction of the arbitrators while entertaining a petition under section 30 to set aside an award.

issues.text: whether grant or refusal of an adjournment by an arbitrator comes within the parameters of section 30 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: and we do number think that grant or refusal of an adjournment by an arbitrator companyes within the parameters of section 30 of the Act. At any rate the arbitrators refusal of an adjournment sought in 1999 in an arbitration proceeding pending since 1995 cannot at all be said to be perverse keeping in mind the object of the Act as an alternate dispute resolution system aimed at speedy resolution of disputes.

arguments.claim: The grounds on which the High Court has set aside the award are not the grounds contemplated under Section 30 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Shri Jaideep Gupta, learned Sr. counsel appearing for appellant herein contended that the grounds on which the High Court has set aside the award are not the grounds contemplated under Section 30 of the Act. He submitted that arbitration proceedings having started in the year 1995 could number be companyleted even in the year 1999 therefore, the High Court ought number to have interfered with the award.

arguments.claim: Arbitrators not justified in denying opportunity to lead evidence given delay in delivering award till November 1999 despite application on 20 May

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the record that there is an application submitted by the petitioner before the Arbitrators on 20th May 1999 regarding the mistake committed by him in recording the date of hearing and requested the Arbitrators to give an opportunity to lead the evidence. One can understand if the Arbitrators have after closing the matter for award have delivered the award immediately but since the Arbitrators had number deliver their award by 20th May 1999, they also did number deliver their award immediately thereafter, but waited till November 1999 to make their award, the Arbitrators could have easily permitted the petitioner to lead evidence. I do number think that the Arbitrators were justified in denying the petitioner an opportunity to lead evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Section 30 of the Arbitration Act 1940 reads thus Grounds for setting aside award. An award shall number be set aside except on one or more of the following grounds, namely a that an arbitrator or umpire has misconducted himself or the proceedings b that an award has been made after the issue of an order by the Court superseding the arbitration or after arbitration proceedings have become invalid under Sec. 35 c that an award has been improperly procured or is otherwise invalid.

arguments.claim: Refusal of adjournment by arbitrator does not constitute misconduct under Sec 30(a); not perverse in long-delayed proceedings aimed at speedy resolution

anchor.surface_text: A bare reading of the said section shows that the civil court has very limited jurisdiction to interfere with an award made by the arbitrators and it certainly does number permit the civil court including the High Court to interfere with the discretionary order of granting or refusing an adjournment. ... At any rate the arbitrators refusal of an adjournment sought in 1999 in an arbitration proceeding pending since 1995 cannot at all be said to be perverse keeping in mind the object of the Act as an alternate dispute resolution system aimed at speedy resolution of disputes.

arguments.claim: If arbitrator's view is possible, court cannot interfere; no closer scrutiny of merits or error apparent on face permits reappraisal

anchor.surface_text: The common phraseology error apparent on the face of the record does number itself, however, mean and imply closer scrutiny of the merits of documents and materials on record. ... If the view of the arbitrator is a possible view the award or the reasoning contained therein cannot be examined.

holdings.text: The learned Single Judge and Division Bench of the High Court were not justified in setting aside the award of the arbitrators solely on the ground that the respondent who failed to appear ought to have been granted another opportunity to produce his evidence.

anchor.surface_text: From the above narrated facts the question that falls for our consideration is whether the learned Single Judge or the Division Bench of the High Court were justified in setting aside the award of the arbitrators solely on the ground that the respondent herein who failed to appear before the arbitrators on a day fixed for his evidence ought to have been granted another opportunity to produce his evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Courts erred by substituting arbitrators' discretionary decision on adjournment, exceeding limited scope under Section 30.

holdings.text: The High Court was not justified in interfering with the discretionary jurisdiction of the arbitrators while entertaining a petition under Section 30 to set aside an award.

anchor.surface_text: In the above circumstances, the question for our consideration is was the High Court justified in interfering with the discretionary jurisdiction of the arbitrators while entertaining a petition under section 30 to set aside an award.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Civil courts have limited jurisdiction under Section 30; cannot interfere with arbitrators' discretionary orders like refusing adjournment.

holdings.text: Grant or refusal of an adjournment by an arbitrator does not come within the parameters of Section 30 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: and we do not think that grant or refusal of an adjournment by an arbitrator comes within the parameters of section 30 of the Act. At any rate the arbitrators refusal of an adjournment sought in 1999 in an arbitration proceeding pending since 1995 cannot at all be said to be perverse keeping in mind the object of the Act as an alternate dispute resolution system aimed at speedy resolution of disputes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 30 restricts interference to specific grounds like misconduct; discretionary procedural decisions not included.

holdings.text: The arbitrators' refusal of an adjournment sought in 1999 in an arbitration proceeding pending since 1995 cannot be said to be perverse keeping in mind the object of the Act as an alternate dispute resolution system aimed at speedy resolution of disputes.

anchor.surface_text: At any rate the arbitrators refusal of an adjournment sought in 1999 in an arbitration proceeding pending since 1995 cannot at all be said to be perverse keeping in mind the object of the Act as an alternate dispute resolution system aimed at speedy resolution of disputes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proceedings delayed from 1995; refusal aligns with speedy resolution purpose; not misconduct or perversity.

holdings.text: Both the learned Single Judge and Division Bench have erred in setting aside the award only with a view to give an opportunity to the defaulting respondent to lead evidence which was rejected by the arbitrators by their reasoned order of 10.5.1999.

anchor.surface_text: We think both the learned Single Judge and Division Bench have erred in setting aside the award only with a view to give an opportunity to the defaulting respondent to lead evidence which was rejected by the arbitrators by their reasoned order of 10.5.1999.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reversal of lower courts' decisions based on misapplication of Section 30 to arbitrators' reasoned procedural order.

holdings.text: Civil court has very limited jurisdiction to interfere with an award made by the arbitrators and it certainly does not permit the civil court including the High Court to interfere with the discretionary order of granting or refusing an adjournment.

anchor.surface_text: A bare reading of the said section shows that the civil court has very limited jurisdiction to interfere with an award made by the arbitrators and it certainly does not permit the civil court including the High Court to interfere with the discretionary order of granting or refusing an adjournment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bare reading of Section 30 limits grounds; discretionary procedural matters outside scope, supported by precedents like Arosan Enterprises.

holdings.text: Refusal to grant further adjournment for evidence after long delay does not constitute misconduct under Section 30(a).

anchor.surface_text: a  that an arbitrator or umpire has misconducted himself or the proceedings

holdings.reasoning_summary: Misconduct under Section 30(a) does not encompass refusal of adjournment in protracted proceedings.

precedents.cited_proposition: Section 30 of the Arbitration Act, 1940 is restrictive; award cannot be set aside except on specified grounds like misconduct; no reappraisal of evidence or interference with arbitrator's view if possible view
precedents.cited_holding: The use of the expression 'shall' ... makes it mandatory ... award shall not be set aside excepting for the grounds as mentioned therein ... Reappraisal of evidence by the court is not permissible
